results.notes: Abundant early summer flush of lobsters under Douglas fir and Western hemlock. This location has had multiple flushes in the last few seasons(In late August and early September 2017-18 for both un-parasitized Russula brevipes and lobsters). We had an unusually warm spike in late June this year and then an abrupt temp drop and heavy rains for a steady week prior to this flush(obviously a micro season created and coaxed both the R. brevipes and H. lactufluorum for this unusually early flush). Added images of my cheesy lobster mushroom soup cook down with broccoli and rice(a family favorite I created and have revised over the years).

results.notes: Fruiting on Oak leaf, solitarily. Macro: Pileus about 1.5 cm wide, whitish (presumably faded a bit), disc having a faint buff-type tone, fragile, margin irregular, slightly lined/wrinkled to somewhat plicate and kind of ‘scalloped’ at margin (but not distinctively pleated); Lamellae white, widely spaced, barely attached to stipe (essentially free); Stipe ~ 1 to 1.5 mm wide and about 5.5-6 cm long, faintly pubescent towards bottom half, glabrous above, 3/4 of stipe dark brown to nearly black, becoming lighter orangish before turning a grey/pallid/white at apex (concolorous with pileus); Odor nondisctintive (did not taste); Micro: Basidiospores elliptical to amygdaliform, hyaline, smooth, ~ 5.0 – 8.0 x 3.0 – 4.0 (4.1) μm, (L’ = 6.24 μm; W’ = 3.46 μm; Q = 1.4 – 2.3; Q’ = 1.8); Cheilocystidia somewhat irregular, narrowly fusiform to cylindrical to narrowly clavate, ~ 15 – 25 × 4 – 9 μm; Pleurocystidia absent or possibly indistinguishable; Basidia clavate, 4-sterigmate, up to around 30 μm long and about 6 – 7 μm wide on average; Lamellar trama septate, with clamps present; Pileipellis a cutis, hyaline in water, pale yellowish in KOH, septate with clamps at nearly every septa, hyphae with scattered bulges, ~ 3 – 7 μm wide.

results.notes: Collected at the edge of a mainly deciduous woodland with some small conifers nearby. Characteristic “yellow patches” are present on volva, stem, and cap. Didn’t;t provide a strong spore print but color was white. This beautiful mushroom was growing in close proximity to other Amanita types.

Collected from mixed mulch, on the edge of a mainly deciduous woodland with some conifers nearby. Brown cap with sparse patches of universal veil…would appreciate help identifying the type…a number of Amanita types were growing in close proximity including Amanita amerirubescens, A. flaviconia, possibly A. pantherina or A. brunnescens? Spore print is white.

A beautiful Amanita collected from leaf litter near a small conifer on the edge of a mainly deciduous woodland. Golden cap with sparse but prominent universal veil remnants. No “yellow patches” to be seen though A. flavoconia was seen nearby. Did not provide a strong spore print but print was white. This mushroom was growing in close proximity to a number of other different Amanita types. Would appreciate help with identification.

results.notes:
Growing gregariously in grass in two caespitose clusters (one consisting of more mature fruitbodies destroyed by mowers) at the base of a planted birch, with three large oaks only 10 yards away. Thought it was a reasonable fit for T. indecisus till I found out it was bitter-tasting.
The macromorphology can be inferred from the photos. This species is characterized by its small size, clustered habit, chocolate-brown caps, smooth, pallid stipes infused with a mix of light brown streaks and a dotted pattern, a strong farinaceous odor and the unpalatable taste.
The birch tree was uprooted and destroyed by a freak wind storm in the spring of 2020. I haven’t seen this mushroom there since then, so it’s possible that birch was the host.

DNA Results & Discussion (posted 7-Jul-20; edited 13-Sep-23):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 855 bps was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. It is fully supported by forward and reverse reads. The full-length ITS1-5.8-ITS2 sequence is 723 bps long. The three loci are 214, 161, and 348 bps long, respectively; the latter one is rather long for a typical ITS2 region in Boletaceae. There are three ambiguous positions: “Y” (C/T) at #168, “M” (A/C) at #189, and “Y” at #626. There is also an unusual – for boletes, that is – mutation in the opening motif of nrLSU (standard = TTGACCTCAAATCA), wherein the “A” immediately preceding the last TCA is replaced by a “G”.
> A BLASTn-100 of the full-length ITS sequence returned a single top hit (720/723 = 99.6% similarity, 100% query cover) with ‘Boletales sp. voucher B1101’ collected in Canada in 1990 by Y. Lamoureux (accession # KY826028). The three mismatches are the ambiguities in MO373952, so, in essence, it’s a perfect match. The next best match at 95-96% similarity are several accessions originating from Floridian vouchers identified as T. rhodoconius (perhaps erroneously), while the other tylopilus accessions that appear on this hit list are less than 86% similar.
Another highly similar recently published GenBank deposit is “Tylopilus aff. rhodoconius voucher iNat66942561” ON943280 is also from Canada. My concept of T. rhodoconius is based on the description by Bessette et al. (the 2000 NAB & 2016 BoENA bolete books), who promoted T. peralbidus var. rhodoconius Singer to it, and is exemplified by my obs 174530, obs 247510 and obs 288807 (all collected in the NJ Pinelands and vouchered); however, they could possibly represent just as many species as only the last voucher was sequenced. The ITS of MO288807 is very different from those of the Floridian "rhodoconius accessions and is instead highly similar to accessions labeled as T. balloui, also originating from Floridian collections. The types of T. peralbidus and T. rhodoconius have not been barcoded yet.
> As I had usually done in the past when dealing with cryptic Canadian hits in GenBank, I contacted Renée Lebeuf and she responded with the following:
“The collection [B1101] you refer to is this one, determined by Lamoureux as T. appalachiensis: https://www.flickr.com/.... Found in Contrecoeur, Quebec, under oak, beech and poplar (no conifer present). Taste bitter, no reticulations on stipe, even at apex. He does not mention the odor. I never found it myself. Yves seems to be the only collector in Quebec, as far as I know. He found a single small basidioma the following year, but despite surveying the collection spot for 15 years afterwards, he never found it again. Nice find!”
> The description of T. appalachiensis on the MycoQuebec website, featuring the same photo, can be found here: https://www.mycoquebec.org/....
I have just created the description of Tylopilus fellus var. minor Coker & Beers by pasting the original one from their 1943 book: https://mushroomobserver.org/name/show_name/19566 (however, as of 13-Sep-23 neither this page, nor the name record itself, exist). Singer renamed what is presumably this taxon to T. appalachiensis (The Agaricales in Modern Taxonomy: 1962, p. 742, as “nom. subnud/”), although Index Fungorum begs to differ.

A single fruitbody growing in leaf litter in soft, moist ground in mixed deciduous woods, with beech and oak nearby. Found along the GT where it zig-zags downhill just to the west of GG.
The cap is definitely zonate, with a yellow-brown (caramel) center, followed by a narrow darker brown band, followed by a caramel-colored zone just above the marginal striations.
The overall fb length is 15.5 cm. The cap “footprint” is ~3.5 cm. The striations are ~0.35R. The gills are 3.5 mm wide. The stipe is 7 mm wide at apex, gradually widening to 1 cm inside the volval sack. The volva is 4 cm tall and is completely subterranean. The stipe is buried in ground to just above the volva (4.5 cm).
This species somewhat reminds of me of what turned out be A. penetrans by DNA, obs 244455, though MO374001 was collected some 100-120 m away and lacked the prominent brownish snakeskin pattern on the stipe seen here.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion:
Unfortunately, the nrITS sequence derived by Dr. Kudzma from this material suffered from extreme heterogeneity in both reads for most sequence length, and, unlike a few manageable cases I worked on, the haplotypes could not separated confidently. However, two resolved, albeit short, single-sequence fragments of ITS1 and ITS2 originating from the adjacent SSU and LSU |shown between the pipes| were salvaged. Regrettably, they are too short to be submitted in GenBank:
5’-end fragment: …|GGATCATTA|TTGAATTGGAAACCCATGGCT….
3’-end fragment: …ATATTGGCTTGAAAAGACAATCGGTGTGATAATCCTCTATGCACCTTGCAAAGTCTTTCAGCCCCTTTTTTATGATTCA|TCTGACCTCAAATCA|…
Note the ‘TCT’ opening motif of the nrLSU locus associated with series Penetratrices vs. the standard ‘TTT’ motif associated with the mainstream sect. Vaginatae.
A BLASTn of the 79 bps ITS2 fragment gave a 100% match to published accessions of the following taxa provisionally named by Dr. Tulloss: ‘justicei’ (2), ‘penetrans’ (3), ‘pinchotensis’ (1), ‘scutum’ (2), and ‘sp-AO3’ (1). Interestingly, all ‘penetrans’ vouchers sequenced by RET to date have been consistent in terms of failing to give up their ITS due to severe heterogeneity. This fact, the zonate pattern of the young MO374011, as well as prior history of penetrans found in these wood all suggest that the present observation is likely to be this taxon than any of the aforementioned taxa. I am still waiting for Dr. RET to weigh in on this provisional ID.

Amanita populiphila
Eden Prairie, Minnesota

- Ecology: Found in two different sites with wooded areas and disturbed grassy spots. Both seemingly associated with nearby cottonwood.

- Cap: About 7cm on mature specimens. striations noticed at margin (6mm long). Convex to flat/upturned in aging specimens. Light brown color overall. Off-white to tan warts. Flesh was white.

- Gills: Appearing free from stem, but really just attached. Off-white color. Close (with some short gills).

- Stem: Approx. 12-14cm in mature. About 1.0-1.5cm wide. Fibrous and more than than off-white. No ring on stem. Very fragile off white with shades of tan/light brown volva. Stuffed center (white).

-Odor/taste: Raw potato

- Spore print: White

- Note: Thanks goes to members of the MN Mycoflora Project. A member had brought in recent specimens which helped me with ID when I found them later.

results.notes:
Habitat: Next to the Appalachian Trail in mixed hardwood and hemlock forest.

Weather Conditions: Humid day in the 80’s and ~60’s overnight. Scattered rain showers the day before and a full day of rain the day before that.

Growth Pattern/Substrate: Growing in clumps and solitary between clumps on well rotted/soaked white birch log on the ground.

Cap: 3-8 cm diameter, flesh: yellow, .5-1 CM thick, convex to broadly convex, sometimes with irregular and undulating margin. Dry, Yellow-Orange in color but turning darker after harvested, with rust colored striations or fibrils, blue green spotting already present on cap. Some with red brown spore deposits form larger mushrooms above. Separable pellicle (not gelatinous). Stained dark brown-black when pinched, bruising seemed to be more blue-green under pellicle (see photos).

Hymenium: Gills; crowded, forked near margin, notched (sinuate). Yellow-Orange in color when collected, soon turning dark brown. Fragile and decaying overnight. Mottled with darker shades of brown. Spore Print: cinnamon to rusty brown.

Stipe: 1-3 cm dia. 3-5 cm in length, somewhat tapered thinner near cap, yellowish tan fibrillose with dark reddish brown fibers. light yellow durable flesh, hollow with some larger specimen housing meal worms. No annulus was present on any of the specimen but, an annual zone present about 1 cm below the attachment to cap with a rust brown ring. More smooth above annual zone of a more solid yellow color.
Smell; indistictive (smelled like a mushroom (earthy)). Taste; Bitter.

Collected spore prints on paper and tin foil overnight.

Soaked in salt water for 24 hours after to remove insects. dehydrated at 140 degrees for 7 hours then lowered temp to 130 for roughly 8 hrs until “cracker” dry.

Collected this solitary mushroom poking through leaf litter a few feet from a small white pine on the edge of a mixed but mainly deciduous woodland. Looks like A. muscaria to me rather than A. flavoconia. Many other species of Amanita are growing in this vicinity, giving me a good lesson regarding how difficult it is to determine species based on gross morphology alone. Collected another solitary mushroom from this same pine that also appeared to be A. muscaria but with a yellow cap and sparser veil fragments. White spore print.

COMMON NAME: Slimy Bitter Cort

MO#: nnnnnn iNat #: nnnnnnnn

NEARBY FLORA: Conifer: Douglas Fir, Hemlock, Western Red Cedar; Deciduous: Red Huckleberry; Evergreen: Black/Purple Huckleberry, Oregon Grape, Sword Ferns.

SUBSTRATE: Moss, Needle Duff, very-well decomposed wood.

HABIT: Single

LIGHT EXPOSURE: partial shade

ODOR: Putrid

TASTE: Ostensibly Bitter

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: Umbonate, with a height of 3mm and at its widest point about 1.5mm; the surface has irregularly sized-and-shaped “warty-bumpy-like” shapes; exterior has a light-tan color and, when cut, the interior has a pale-yellow color around the Margin.

VEIL: Still attached to the Cap Margin and appears to be very robust with an external color of pale yellow.

GILLS: Gills appear adnexed and a light chocolate color.

STIPE: Exterior has irregularly shaped, vertically running ridges and is almost bone-white with a hint of tan; interior of the Stipe within the Cap and Veil zone has a pale yellow color, like the Cap Margin interior, that runs down slightly past the veil. Remainder of Stipe color is a pale Neapolitan-yellow-like color with the flesh being vertically fibrous. The Base is visibly, but slightly, bulbous

SPORES: Ostensibly Rusty Brown

results.notes:
1. Stipe partially stuffed, partially hollow.
2. Pileus umbonate to nearly papillate.
3. Oxidizing blue on all major physical parts.
4. Oxidizing blue then charcoal black on all stipes. Some white areas remain 24 hours later, but very few.
5. Bulbous or sub-bulbous stem bases.
6. Gills colored medium brown and oxidizing blue.
7. Stipes feel very strong but can be imagined as having a feeling in-hand like a miniature bamboo rod.
8. Subtle striations appear vertically from the pilei margins to about half-way up the pilei.
9. Pileipellis hygrophanous.
10. An emerald-like, green hue appeared in only one place: The apex of the umbo-papilla in one of the tiniest specimens.

Habitat: A cloud forest in MEXICO. The highest 700 feet of a single mountain. A gully-like area where rainfall gathers and travels downward. Among living, woody small plant-life and decaying twigs/branches and leaves. Well shaded area. Moist sand mixed with clay or clay-like deposits attached well to the stipe bases. Growing spread-out but close-by as individuals, with a couple of them joined together strongly.
Comments: Spore print = none taken. There are no visible purple or purplish spore deposits anywhere that I can see. There are shining, reflective sapphire pink granules in the substrate (observed at +/- 5x magnification). Not all of the pilei dry in a total hygrophanous manner (in example, they do not all turn from dark brown to light brown upon drying). There are dark areas that remain upon drying, particularly where striations are present. Also, this collection retains a significant portion of its size upon drying.
